awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track B: Community Informed AI-Based System for Driver Training to Advance Neurodiverse Independence and Employment
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2022, approximately 70,000 young adults with autism will leave high school and face a litany of disheartening statistics regarding independent living, community participation, and employment. Adults with autism rate employment as their top concern.  A major impediment for autistic individuals to access work opportunities specifically is lack of independence with transportation; fewer than a third of driving-age individuals with autism are licensed to drive while many more are capable with the right training. This project offers a community-driven planning process to explore how a prototype of an advanced artificial-intelligence-based driving-training (AIDT) system, specifically designed for neurodiverse individuals, that together with a curriculum built on a cognitive behavioral intervention for driving, can offer an effective solution for communities to help capable autistic individual become licensed drivers, who are confident in their driving ability and able to more fully participate in community life.

This Stage-1 project seeks to plan for a full pilot deployment with multiple types of civic partners and support providers – including community-based training centers and clinics, schools, and others – toward an effective, low-cost, commercializable, driving-instruction platform, with a value proposition that offers increased independence and expanded career options for individuals with autism. An AIDT prototype has been tested and demonstrated in Nashville, Tennessee, and San Diego, California. The research in this Planning Grant will involve a large group of civic entities in a community-engaged, mixed methods quantitative and qualitative data collection process to identify context determinants that are important to address within the AIDT system and in constructing a training protocol in preparation for Stage-2 pilot deployment across vocational rehabilitation, clinical services and education sites. The project expects to learn how to make the AIDT system adaptable to use within multiple employment contexts and multiple employment outcomes of relevance to stakeholder communities, how to make the AIDT outputs responsive to community service providers’ needs for maximal useability and minimal training demands, and how to finance its long-term sustainment and growth. 

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program — Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs — and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One in 36 individuals in the US has autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Some 85% of adults with autism are unemployed or under-employed relative to their abilities. This persistent unemployment challenge exacts massive costs: The estimated cost of supporting Americans with autism having limited employment prospects will grow to $461 billion per year by 2025. A growing number of major employers have initiated “autism at work” programs to intentionally recruit autistic individuals for meaningful and gainful employment. However, a major impediment for autistic individuals to access these work opportunities specifically, let alone to maximize their future career options generally, is their lack of independence with transportation: fewer than 25% of driving-age autistic individuals are licensed to drive. In order to address this challenge, we proposed to introduce a novel virtual reality-based driving simulator embedded with artificial intelligence and unobtrusive biosensors together with a driving curriculum based on cognitive behavioral intervention specifically designed for neurodiverse individuals to a set of civic partners and stakeholders to assess its viability.

 

The central research question for our Stage 1 planning project was: How could we package the AI-based Vehicle Technology Simulator with Behavioral Strategies (AI-VTSBS) system for seamless deployment, effectively train service providers in its use, and develop mechanisms for financial sustainability? The research in Stage 1 involved a large group of civic entities and members in a community-engaged, mixed methods quantitative and qualitative data collection process to identify context determinants that are important to address within the AI-VTSBS system and in constructing a training protocol needing to be developed for Stage 2 pilot deployment across a variety of  critical service settings: vocational rehabilitation, clinical services, and education sites. Stage 1 research activities provided rich preliminary information regarding implementation, useability of system outputs, and project sustainability. Two research activities were conducted: 1) Community forum meetings were held with civic partners and their networks (self-advocates, families, clinicians, educators, vocational rehabilitation counselors, administrators) to provide information on such delivery factors as setting, equipment available, time allowance, duration of services, funding mechanisms. Thes forums collected qualitative information through focus group type discussions with community stakeholders across the 3 service settings with a total of 10 stakeholders (3 vocational, 4 schools, 2 clinics, 1 consumer network). We had a 100% participation rate. Stakeholders reiterated with conviction the desire for an evidence-based driving intervention and the high-need problem area to address- driving- because nothing currently exists, and all of the service settings have transportation goals necessary for employment and independence for adult consumers. 2) Alpha test of the AI-VTSBS system was conducted in one behavioral health clinic in San Diego and in 1 clinic in Tennessee. Six autistic participants (4 females, 2 males; 15.5-23 yrs) participated in the AI-VTSBS 9-week program which included 8 groups sessions (delivering the Cognitive Behavioral Intervention for Driving curriculum) and 5 individual driving coaching sessions (completing 6 driving levels and ~18 total drive scenarios). Results indicated positive feasibility as staff were trained to fidelity, all participants completed the program, equipment was used successfully (with some adjustments) and participants attended driving sessions with driving coach (95% time). The program was found to be overall acceptable.  In a separate study, in collaboration with the Amerigroup Insurance Company, one of our civic partners, we explored how we could create a reimbursement mechanism for the driving training of autistic clients. In an exploratory study, we deployed the driving training simulator at a clinic in Knoxville, TN that developed a reimbursement pathway with Amerigroup for driving training using our simulator. Five individuals went through the system (4 male, 1 female), ranging in age from 16 to 27 with an average age of 22. We learned that the basic simulator could function in a commercial setting with minimal technical help, and more importantly, the clinic got reimbursed for their services, indicating a potential path for financial sustainment. Taken together these Stage 1 studies provided rich information from civic partners and community participants to make a first round of adaptations to prepare AI-VTSBS for successful multi-state, multi-setting and multi-program site deployment and for the proposed implementation study for Stage 2, which we are currently pursuing.

 

The outcome of this project has the potential to strengthen the foundation of an inclusive society in which the tools, platforms, and models to be developed will facilitate meaningful employment for all individuals in general and individuals with ASD in particular. Since many autistic individuals have unique capabilities, optimizing their workforce engagement would transform what is currently an enormous societal cost, instead adding significant value to the human resources of companies, to the economy as a whole and, aspirationally, to all individuals.
